Wait, the XOR operator in Fortran is IEOR. So r starts at 0, then for each element in a, r = IEOR(r, a(i)). Yes. Then, first_output_first_element = IEOR(r, a(1)). Then, N is this value. Then compute the second step's answer (ans). To compute the number of digits in N:

children.text:
Read input

read*, n

allocate(a(n))

read*, a

! Compute r as XOR of all elements

r = 0

do i=1, n

   r = ieor(r, a(i)) end do

! Compute first element of first program's output (N)

N = ieor(r, a(1))

! Compute second step's ans

! First, count digits in N

count =0

temp = N

do while (temp >0)

   count = count +1

   temp = temp /10

end do

ans =0

do i=1, count

   if (i < count) then

      if (mod(i,2) ==1) then

         ans = ans + (10**i - 10**(i-1))

      end if

   else

      if (mod(count,2) ==1) then

         ans = ans + (N - 10**(count-1) +1)

      end if

   end if

end do

! Compute third step's result

third_result = (ans /3)*2

if (mod(ans,3) /=0) then

   third_result = third_result +1

end if

!

program main

implicit none

integer :: n, i, r, N, count, temp, ans, third_result

integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: a

! Read input

read*, n

allocate(a(n))

read*, a

! Compute r as XOR of all elements

r = 0

do i=1, n

   r = ieor(r, a(i))

end do

! Compute first element of first program's output (N)

N = ieor(r, a(1))

! Compute second step's ans

! First, count digits in N

count =0

temp = N

do while (temp >0)

   count = count +1

   temp = temp /10

end do

ans =0

do i=1, count

   if (i < count) then

      if (mod(i,2) ==1) then

         ans = ans + (10**i - 10**(i-1))

      end if

   else

      if (mod(count,2) ==1) then

         ans = ans + (N - 10**(count-1) +1)

      end if

   end if

end do

! Compute third step's result

third_result = (ans /3)*2

if (mod(ans,3) /=0) then

   third_result = third_result +1

end if

! Output the result

print*, third_result

deallocate(a)

end program main
